Regional cooperation was encouraged, including border agreements with Serbia and Bulgaria, while criticizing “antiquisation” historical narratives. The Parliament underscored the urgency of resolving the name dispute to uphold EU enlargement credibility and regional stability, advocating for an EU arbitration mechanism to address bilateral conflicts.

title: 2012 progress report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the 2012 Progress Report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia
background: Following the 2005 EU candidate status, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia engaged in accession reforms under the High-Level Accession Dialogue while facing unresolved bilateral disputes, political instability, and inter-ethnic challenges. The Parliament will discuss the country's progress towards EU membership and obstacles to initiating accession negotiations.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly supports initiating EU accession negotiations with Macedonia without delay, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to Balkan stability and merit-based enlargement.  
EPP approves the issue's rejection of bilateral disputes as accession blockers but proposes enhanced UN-mediated diplomatic mechanisms to resolve the name issue concurrently with early-stage negotiations.  
EPP applauds Macedonia's 75% HLAD reform progress and urges immediate Commission screening to formalize technical readiness, ensuring alignment with EPP's 2023 enlargement acceleration priorities.  
EPP emphasizes Macedonia's need to strengthen educational reforms addressing historical narratives and inter-ethnic cohesion, framing this as an enhancement opportunity to solidify European identity-building.  
EPP endorses judicial independence benchmarks while suggesting accelerated implementation of asset confiscation frameworks to meet anti-corruption targets, reflecting EPP's rule-of-law red lines.

EFD rejects the issue's approach to accession negotiations as dangerously detached from FYROM's unaddressed nationalism and anti-democratic governance under VMRO's prolonged rule.  
EFD opposes fundamentally the claim that bilateral disputes shouldn't block talks, emphasizing Skopje's 20-year failure to resolve identity provocations contradicts EU neighborhood principles.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects like systematic Greek-baiting in education and public monuments that perpetuate historical revisionism incompatible with EU values.  
This entirely conflicts with EFD's position that FYROM's EU prospects require prior elimination of irredentist rhetoric targeting Greek Macedonia's sovereignty.  
The issue fails to address VMRO's institutionalized ethnic divisiveness, evidenced by Skopje's stagnant governance versus Athens' seven peaceful power transitions since 1991.

GREEN_EFA strongly approves the immediate commencement of EU accession negotiations, aligning perfectly with its longstanding commitment to regional stability and democratic integration in the Western Balkans.  
GREEN_EFA approves the issue’s decoupling of bilateral name disputes from the negotiation launch, urging proactive diplomacy to resolve this issue in line with UN frameworks before final accession.  
GREEN_EFA proposes strengthening protections for LGBT rights and press freedom, emphasizing urgent legislative action to enable safe public assemblies like Pride events and combat self-censorship in media.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the focus on judicial independence and anti-corruption reforms, which mirror its 2012 priorities for accountable governance and rule-of-law alignment.  
GREEN_EFA highlights youth unemployment as a critical area for enhanced EU investment, aligning with its social justice agenda to address economic disparities through green infrastructure projects like Corridor X.

ALDE strongly agrees the immediate commencement of EU accession negotiations, aligning perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to advancing European integration and countering regional stagnation.  
ALDE approves the issue’s emphasis on resolving bilateral disputes through dialogue rather than preconditions, urging intensified EU mediation to mirror the Serbia-Kosovo normalization model as a template.  
ALDE highlights the need to enhance media freedom safeguards, proposing explicit benchmarks for reducing self-censorship and reversing declining press freedom rankings through Commission-monitored reforms.  
ALDE commends the focus on inter-ethnic cohesion but urges accelerated educational reforms to institutionalize multi-ethnic values, addressing Helsinki Committee concerns about rising hate crimes.  
ALDE aligns with the demand for judicial independence and anti-corruption measures, stressing that asset confiscation systems must meet EU best practices before accession talks conclude.

SD strongly advocates the immediate commencement of EU accession negotiations, aligning with the issue’s urgency to prevent regional destabilization and honor four years of Commission recommendations.  
SD applauds the recognition of High-Level Accession Dialogue progress but emphasizes formal negotiations must begin to institutionalize judicial independence and media freedom reforms.  
SD proposes enhancing inter-ethnic cohesion efforts by amending educational reforms to explicitly mandate multi-ethnic history curricula, addressing concerns raised about democratic credibility.  
SD underscores the critical need for bilateral dialogue on the name issue, urging the Council to facilitate structured mediation while maintaining negotiation momentum.  
SD strongly endorses prioritizing youth employment through accelerated EU funding for Corridor X/VIII infrastructure projects, directly tackling economic stagnation risks.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue’s framing of the name dispute as a bilateral issue, which totally disputes with their stance that it requires international issue under UN oversight and contradicts principles of good neighborliness.  
GUE_NGL opposes the omission of December 2012 political events, highlighting the issue’s failure to address undemocratic practices and the urgent need for substantive democratic reforms in FYROM.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s neoliberal economic prescriptions, which overlook the catastrophic youth and female unemployment rates caused by EU-mandated austerity policies, inconsistent with their anti-capitalist agenda.  
GUE_NGL opposes FYROM’s EU accession talks, denouncing the issue’s alignment with imperialist interventions in Bosnia and Herzegovina and NATO-backed agendas that undermine national self-determination.  
GUE_NGL rejects the issue’s superficial calls for inter-ethnic cohesion, arguing it fuels nationalism by ignoring internal ethnic tensions and failing to prioritize grassroots anti-imperialist solidarity over EU-mediated compromises.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the prolonged delay in opening EU accession negotiations with the candidate country, despite four consecutive years of positive recommendations from the Commission, warning that this risks exacerbating domestic frustrations and regional tensions. It urged the Council to set a negotiation date without further delay, emphasizing that bilateral disputes, including the unresolved name issue with Greece (referencing UN resolutions and the 1995 Interim Accord), should not block the start of talks but must be resolved before accession. The resolution highlighted progress under the High-Level Accession Dialogue (HLAD), with over 75% of policy areas advancing, but stressed that HLAD is not a substitute for formal negotiations, calling for immediate screening by the Commission. It underscored the importance of good neighborly relations, inter-ethnic cohesion, and regional cooperation, welcoming efforts to address tensions through dialogue with Bulgaria and Greece, while condemning ethnic intolerance and urging educational reforms to foster multi-ethnic values. Key domestic priorities included judicial independence, anti-corruption measures (noting gaps in asset confiscation and high-level convictions), media freedom (citing concerns over self-censorship and declining press freedom rankings), and reforms in public administration, decentralization (targeting 9% of GDP for local spending), and anti-discrimination policies, including support for LGBT rights and Roma inclusion. Economic challenges such as high youth unemployment (among the world’s highest), weak fiscal governance, and infrastructure development (e.g., Corridor X and VIII projects) were addressed, alongside environmental and climate alignment efforts. The Parliament also demanded compliance with the European Court of Human Rights’ ruling on the El-Masri case, including compensation and an apology, and stressed the need for civil society engagement in EU integration processes.

title: 2013 progress report on Serbia: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the 2013 progress report on Serbia
background: Following the EU's 2003 Thessaloniki commitments and Serbia's 2013 Stabilisation and Association Agreement implementation, alongside the April 2013 Kosovo normalization agreement and June 2013 Council decision to open accession talks, the Parliament will discuss Serbia's EU membership progress regarding compliance criteria, regional cooperation, and Kosovo relations.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the opening of EU accession negotiations with Serbia, aligning with EPP's commitment to European integration and regional stability through the Belgrade-Pristina dialogue.  
EPP applauds Serbia's progress on judicial reforms and anti-corruption measures, urging enhanced decentralization to strengthen subsidiarity in line with EU governance principles.  
EPP emphasizes the critical need for balanced minority rights protections, proposing reciprocal standards for Serbian minorities in Kosovo and Kosovo Serbs to advance mutual trust.  
EPP endorses strict monitoring of constitutional reforms to address Kosovo’s status and enhance local autonomy in Vojvodina, ensuring alignment with EU values of territorial cohesion.  
EPP recommends accelerating economic governance reforms, particularly SME support and fiscal consolidation, to meet 2020 renewable energy targets under the Energy Community Treaty.

EFD absolutely challenges the issue's failure to address imminent social unrest risks in Serbia, directly conflicting with EFD's warnings about EU-induced economic destabilization and impoverishment.  
EFD rejects the normalization of Vučić's authoritarian power consolidation, contradicting EFD's principles against centralized governance and historical ties to the Milošević regime.  
EFD opposes the allocation of €1.385 billion in pre-accession funds to Serbia, totally disapproveing with EFD's stance against fiscal irresponsibility during EU internal crises.  
EFD rejects Kosovo's integration progress due to unaddressed corruption and immigration risks, opposing labor market threats to member states like Italy.

GREEN_EFA strongly advocates the opening of EU accession negotiations with Serbia, particularly endorsing the focus on judicial independence and comprehensive normalization of relations with Kosovo as vital for regional stability.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s emphasis on minority rights protections, including Roma inclusion and LGBTI equality, which aligns perfectly with their longstanding commitment to social justice and anti-discrimination frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA welcomes the renewable energy targets under the Energy Community Treaty, recognizing this as a critical step toward Serbia’s alignment with EU climate goals and sustainable development priorities.  
GREEN_EFA proposes strengthening provisions for Kosovo’s judiciary by urging EU member states to second more qualified personnel to EULEX, ensuring robust anti-corruption mechanisms without opposing the issue’s core structure.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the need for accelerated implementation of war crimes cooperation mechanisms, particularly regarding ICTY collaboration, to reinforce transitional justice as a cornerstone of EU integration.

ALDE strongly sanctions the opening of EU accession negotiations with Serbia, aligning perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to Western Balkan integration and transformative democratic reforms.  
ALDE applauds the First Agreement on Principles of Normalisation with Kosovo as a critical advancement in regional stability and urges accelerated implementation of mutual legal assistance frameworks.  
ALDE proposes enhancing civil society engagement in Serbia’s reform process to ensure transparency, particularly in judiciary reforms and anti-corruption measures outlined in Chapter 23.  
ALDE emphasizes the need for EU Member States to harmonize their stance on Kosovo’s recognition to strengthen regional cohesion, framing this as an enhancement opportunity for broader EU consensus.  
ALDE strongly approves the issue’s focus on renewable energy targets and SME development, which align with ALDE’s 2013 priorities for sustainable economic governance.

SD strongly approves the commencement of EU accession negotiations with Serbia, recognizing the transformative April 2013 normalization agreement with Kosovo as fully aligning with SD’s strategic vision for conflict issue through European integration.  

SD applauds the issue’s focus on judicial reforms and anti-corruption frameworks, which directly advance SD’s longstanding priorities for institutional accountability and rule of law in enlargement processes.  

SD proposes strengthening monitoring protocols for Kosovo’s Serbian minority integration to ensure tangible implementation of mutual recognition agreements, while fully endorsing the January 2014 intergovernmental conference timeline.  

SD emphasizes the critical need to accelerate renewable energy alignment with EU targets through technical assistance programs, reflecting SD’s climate governance commitments in the Western Balkans.  

SD totally upholds parallel progress in Serbia’s accession and Kosovo’s Stabilisation and Association Agreement negotiations, urging immediate EU consensus to overcome recognition obstacles through enhanced diplomatic coordination.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's reliance on neoliberal austerity measures and privatization, which deepen unemployment and social inequality, directly opposing the party's anti-capitalist principles.  
GUE_NGL completely againsts the EU’s coercive use of Serbia’s accession process to legitimize Kosovo’s independence, violating Serbia’s sovereignty and international law.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s endorsement of NATO/EU militarization in the Balkans, which entrenched protectorates and capitalist exploitation instead of genuine self-determination.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue’s failure to address the EU’s role in enforcing destructive market reforms, exacerbating poverty and migration contrary to workers’ interests.  
GUE_NGL opposes the EU’s “normalization” framework as imperialist diplomacy, prioritizing geopolitical control over grassroots reconciliation and socialist alternatives.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the decision to open EU accession negotiations with Serbia following the European Council’s June 2013 agreement, contingent on Serbia meeting criteria such as judicial reforms, anti-corruption measures, and normalization of relations with Kosovo. It welcomed the Stabilisation and Association Agreement’s entry into force (1 September 2013) and the First Agreement on Principles of Normalisation with Kosovo (19 April 2013), urging full implementation of these accords, including cooperation on missing persons, mutual legal assistance, and integration of Serbian minorities in Kosovo. The resolution emphasized the need for systemic reforms in judiciary independence, public administration, media freedom, minority rights (notably Roma inclusion and LGBTI protections), economic governance, and energy policy alignment with EU targets, including renewable energy goals under the 2012 Energy Community Treaty. It called for stronger anti-corruption efforts, adoption of whistleblower laws, and resolution of war crimes through cooperation with the ICTY and regional partners. Economic priorities included fiscal consolidation, SME support, and labor market reforms, while social measures highlighted gender equality, civil society engagement, and addressing discrimination. The Parliament stressed regional cooperation, resolution of bilateral disputes (e.g., with Croatia on border demarcation and war crimes), and support for Serbia’s EU integration through structured dialogue, including parliamentary oversight and civil society involvement. Key deadlines included holding the first intergovernmental conference by January 2014 and meeting 2020 renewable energy targets, with ongoing monitoring of progress in these areas.

title: 2013 review of the organisation and functioning of the EEAS: RECOMMENDATION to the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy and Vice President of the European Commission, to the Council and to the Commission on the 2013 review of the organisation and the functioning of the EEAS
background: The 2010 Lisbon Treaty established the European External Action Service (EEAS) to support the EU's unified foreign policy, with a mandated 2013 review of its structure and operations. Challenges included institutional integration, resource allocation, and coherence in addressing global crises and diplomatic priorities. The Parliament will discuss the EEAS's organizational effectiveness and strategic alignment with EU external action objectives.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly sanctions the EEAS review's emphasis on operational efficiency, aligning with EPP's commitment to a coherent EU foreign policy that leverages Member States' diplomatic expertise.  
EPP proposes enhancing delegation heads' strategic focus by reallocating administrative tasks to junior staff, ensuring optimal use of senior diplomatic resources.  
EPP applauds the issue's call to eliminate institutional fragmentation, urging accelerated integration of Commission crisis management tools under EEAS leadership.  
EPP endorses leveraging Member States' ministerial networks for specialized task forces, as exemplified by successful EU coordination in Egypt and Yemen.  
EPP emphasizes the need to maintain geographic balance in senior EEAS roles while fully utilizing diplomats from newer Member States with regional expertise.

EFD rejects the premise of a unified EU foreign policy, fundamentally condemning with EFD's position that national sovereignty precludes meaningful common external action among 27 divergent member states.  
EFD opposes the issue's resource allocation proposals, highlighting the EEAS' structural redundancy and wasteful duplication of national diplomatic services already facing austerity-driven closures.  
EFD fundamentally disputes the EEAS' legitimacy, asserting the proposal overlooks critical aspects such as the EU's lack of federal statehood required for cohesive foreign policy formulation.  
EFD criticizes the issue for failing to address core contradictions in maintaining parallel EU and national diplomatic networks, inconsistent with fiscal responsibility and subsidiarity principles.  
EFD contends continued EEAS funding exemplifies supranational overreach, directly diminishing member states' global influence through forced participation in non-consensual initiatives.

ALDE strongly agrees the issue’s emphasis on streamlining EEAS decision-making structures, which aligns perfectly with ALDE’s longstanding commitment to agile, supranationally coherent EU external action.  
ALDE endorses the call for equitable geographical representation in EEAS staffing, particularly to rectify the overrepresentation of older Member States, advancing ALDE’s priority of inclusive EU institutional design.  
ALDE proposes enhancing the High Representative’s effectiveness through formalized political deputies, a minor structural modification to address role overload while maintaining strong backing for the EEAS’s mandate.  
ALDE strongly agrees closing under-resourced delegations and reallocating resources to crisis zones, reflecting ALDE’s focus on strategic prioritization in foreign policy.  
ALDE approves the issue’s push for gender balance in senior roles, urging accelerated progress to align with ALDE’s equality-driven governance principles.

SD strongly promotes the issue’s emphasis on strengthening the EEAS’s leadership in coordinating EU external policies, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to a unified foreign policy rooted in human rights and strategic clarity.  
SD applauds the focus on gender balance and equitable geographical representation in EEAS staffing, recognizing this as critical to ensuring the service reflects Europe’s diversity and democratic values.  
SD endorses enhanced parliamentary oversight and streamlined crisis management mechanisms, particularly urging faster resource mobilization to address emergencies like the Mali conflict.  
SD highlights the need to further improve consular coordination in EU delegations, proposing clearer protocols for citizen protection during crises as a key enhancement opportunity.  
SD fully backs efforts to deepen Policy Coherence for Development, urging stricter alignment of trade, energy, and security policies with sustainable development goals.

ECR rejects the issue's expansion of EEAS authority as a direct threat to national sovereignty in foreign policy decision-making.  
ECR opposes fundamentally any move toward qualified majority voting on CFSP matters, which would force Member States into costly actions against their interests.  
ECR condemns the issue’s failure to address EEAS budget excesses, including lavish spending and top-heavy bureaucracy inconsistent with austerity principles.  
ECR highlights the issue’s neglect of geographical staffing imbalances, particularly underrepresentation of diplomats from Poland and other newer Member States.  
ECR disputes the premise of centralizing crisis response mechanisms, asserting that British and French troops should not bear disproportionate burdens under EU command.

GUE_NGL firmly condemns with the issue’s militarization of EU external action, rejecting its emphasis on battle groups and crisis management operations as endorsements of imperialist interventionism.  
GUE_NGL opposes the EEAS’s undemocratic structure, condemning its detachment from parliamentary control and alignment with NATO’s aggressive military agenda.  
GUE_NGL rejects the issue’s failure to prioritize disarmament, highlighting its inconsistency with demands for political conflict issue and demilitarized cooperation.  
GUE_NGL condemns the proposed "operational headquarters" and accelerated military funding as escalations of the EU’s role in global militarization.  
GUE_NGL dismisses the issue’s claims of democratic oversight as a facade to legitimize undemocratic, security-driven foreign policies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and recommendations regarding the European External Action Service (EEAS), emphasizing the need to enhance its efficiency, coherence, and accountability in EU external action. It highlighted structural challenges, including a top-heavy hierarchy, slow decision-making in crises like Mali, and insufficient resource reallocation to match strategic priorities. The resolution stressed the importance of streamlining the EEAS to ensure a comprehensive approach, improve coordination with Commission services (notably on development policy and crisis management), and address imbalances in staffing, with 39.5% of EU ambassadors coming from Member States and a one-third target for staff from national diplomatic services, while noting underrepresentation of women in senior roles (AD positions) and overrepresentation in administrative (AST) roles. It called for stronger parliamentary oversight, better financial management to expedite crisis aid, and reforms to delegations, including closing or staffing 36 under-resourced missions. The EEAS was urged to prioritize Policy Coherence for Development, enhance gender and geographical balance, and adopt synergies with Member States’ diplomatic services. Longer-term recommendations included renaming the EEAS and advancing CFSP/CSDP reforms in a future Convention, alongside improving training, security for delegations, and operational efficiency through revised service-level agreements with EU institutions.

title: Iraq – in particular the death penalty (including the case of Tariq Aziz) and attacks against Christian communities: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on Iraq: the death penalty (notably the case of Tariq Aziz) and attacks against Christian communities
background: In 2010, Iraq's Supreme Court sentenced former official Tariq Aziz to death amid ongoing executions, while attacks on Christian communities, including a Baghdad church siege killing 50, escalated displacement. The Parliament will discuss Iraq's application of capital punishment and protection of religious minorities against sectarian violence.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the issue's failure to mandate binding human rights conditions in EU-Iraq economic agreements, inconsistent with Mario Mauro's demand for treaty-based accountability.  
EPP opposes fundamentally the omission of explicit religious freedom clauses in future EU treaties, contradicting Tunne Kelam's call for systematic policy integration.  
EPP condemns the issue's silence on removing religious affiliation from Iraqi identity documents, disregarding Sergio Silvestris' structural reform proposal.  
EPP highlights the absence of requirements for regular Commission reporting on Christian persecution, conflicting with Bernd Posselt's insistence on sustained EU oversight.  
EPP notes the issue's inadequate linkage between EU cooperation and measurable security improvements for minorities, failing Esther de Lange's partnership conditionality principle.

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's omission of foreign occupation forces' responsibility in creating conditions for sectarian violence, contradicting their anti-imperialist foreign policy principles.  
The proposal absolutely conflicts with GREEN_EFA's demand for asylum guarantees by failing to prohibit EU states from deporting persecuted Iraqi Christians to active danger zones.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the narrow legalistic approach to human rights that ignores systemic oppression under current Iraqi authorities backed by Western military interests.  
This issue's silence on arms exports to Iraqi security forces directly undermines GREEN_EFA's stance against militarization fueling minority persecution.  
The lack of reparations for occupation-era crimes against civilians violates GREEN_EFA's transitional justice requirements for true reconciliation.

ALDE rejects the issue’s emphasis on halting Tariq Aziz’s execution, fundamentally doubting with ALDE’s principle that political accountability for grave human rights violations must be pursued rigorously.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as the systemic failure to dismantle sectarian power structures enabling violence against Christians, which ALDE prioritizes in conflict issue frameworks.  
ALDE opposes the issue’s implicit tolerance of delayed justice, inconsistent with ALDE’s demand for immediate ratification of the Second Optional Protocol to abolish Iraq’s death penalty regime entirely.  
This issue inadequately addresses the urgency of EU-led security guarantees for religious minorities, a gap that contradicts ALDE’s advocacy for enforceable international protections.

SD rejects the issue's singular focus on Christian persecution as inconsistent with S&D's principle of universal human rights protection, noting Ana Gomes' emphasis that Muslim majorities bear the greatest brunt of sectarian violence.  
SD opposes the issue's failure to address US accountability for destabilizing Iraq, contradicting Justas Paleckis' assertion that post-invasion chaos requires international responsibility.  
SD absolutely challenges with the issue's death penalty stance by demanding abolition for all cases, not just Tariq Aziz, aligning with Ana Gomes' call for unconditional opposition to capital punishment.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as equal protection for all religious minorities beyond Christians, mirroring Mitro Repo's insistence on unconditional freedom of conscience for every Iraqi citizen.  
SD rejects the issue's narrow security approach, arguing it neglects root causes of sectarian divisions exacerbated by foreign occupation, as highlighted across all S&D interventions.

ECR rejects the issue’s constrained approach to protecting Iraqi Christians, arguing it capitulates to political correctness rather than demanding urgent diplomatic prioritization of religious freedom.  
ECR opposes the failure to explicitly center Christian persecution as a flagship issue in EU foreign policy, inconsistent with their principle that religious liberty must define European diplomacy.  
ECR objects to the issue’s reliance on symbolic constitutional protections (Articles 10, 43) without concrete EU-backed security measures to halt the extinction of Assyrian communities.  
The proposal completely challenges with ECR’s stance by avoiding demands for systemic political reforms in Iraq to dismantle sectarian discrimination against minorities.  
ECR condemns the issue’s self-censorship, which undermines robust advocacy for persecuted Christians, and insists on explicit condemnation of Islamist groups like the Islamic State of Iraq.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue for completely condemning with their comprehensive human rights principles by narrowly focusing on select issues while ignoring systemic abuses by Iraqi and occupying forces.  
GUE_NGL opposes the issue’s failure to address the torture and arbitrary detention of thousands, inconsistent with their stance against state violence and militarized oppression.  
GUE_NGL highlights the proposal’s omission of gender-based violence in Iraq, particularly on the International Day of Violence against Women, as a critical oversight undermining universal rights.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s Western-centric framing, which overlooks U.S. accountability for abandoning Ashraf camp refugees and perpetuates neo-colonial human rights narratives.  
GUE_NGL underscores the contradiction in demanding Iraqi accountability while ignoring constitutional violations by foreign forces, contrary to their anti-imperialist commitments.

resolution: The European Parliament raised deep concerns over Iraq’s Supreme Court sentencing of 74-year-old former deputy premier Tariq Aziz and two others to death, urging Iraqi authorities to halt the execution and reconsider the decision, while welcoming President Talabani’s refusal to ratify the sentence. It reiterated the EU’s firm opposition to the death penalty globally, emphasizing its incompatibility with human dignity and rights, and called on Iraq to adopt an immediate moratorium, ratify the Second Optional Protocol to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, and ensure accountability for human rights violations through rule of law. The resolution also strongly condemned escalating violence against Iraq’s Christian communities, including the October 2010 Baghdad cathedral attack that killed over 50 worshippers, subsequent bombings in November 2010 killing five in Baghdad and two in Mosul, and threats by the Islamic State of Iraq. It highlighted the displacement of hundreds of thousands of Christians due to persecution, risking the extinction of ancient Assyrian communities, and urged Iraqi authorities to uphold constitutional protections for religious freedom (Articles 10 and 43), enhance security for minorities, prosecute perpetrators, and counter sectarian violence. The Parliament reaffirmed solidarity with victims’ families, stressed the need for national reconciliation, and called on the EU and international community to intensify efforts against terrorism targeting religious groups.

title: Kosovo: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the European integration process of Kosovo
background: Kosovo's 2008 unilateral independence declaration, partial EU member state recognition, and unresolved status under UNSCR 1244, alongside EU commitments to Western Balkan integration since 2003, institutional challenges in rule of law, ethnic tensions, and visa liberalization delays formed the context. The Parliament will discuss Kosovo's European integration process amid geopolitical sensitivities and institutional reform requirements.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves Kosovo's European integration process as aligning with EPP's longstanding commitment to democratic consolidation in the Western Balkans, particularly endorsing visa liberalization upon meeting benchmarks.  
EPP applauds the issue's emphasis on extending EULEX's rule-of-law mandate across all territories, mirroring EPP's 2023 Balkan Stability Initiative priorities.  
EPP urges accelerated implementation of minority protection mechanisms for Serbian enclaves, proposing enhanced monitoring frameworks to "strengthen integration" rather than merely "note progress".  
EPP proposes encouraging renewed Pristina-Belgrade technical dialogue on customs and energy through amended mediation protocols in Article 9.  
EPP entirely agrees transforming the EU Liaison Office into a full delegation, aligning with EPP's 2021 position on streamlined external action post-Lisbon.

EFD rejects the issue’s premise of Kosovo’s independence, absolutely againsting with EFD’s position that Kosovo remains an integral part of Serbia under international law.  
EFD opposes EU alignment efforts with Kosovo’s unilateral independence declaration, which contradicts Serbia’s sovereignty and undermines regional stability.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as the unresolved status under the International Court of Justice, rendering EU accession talks premature and legally baseless.  
EFD condemns the issue’s pressure on non-recognizing EU states, asserting this violates national sovereignty and exacerbates Balkan divisions.  
This approach dangerously legitimizes separatist movements, inconsistent with EFD’s commitment to territorial integrity and rule-based international order.

GREEN_EFA strongly upholds the issue’s affirmation of Kosovo’s European integration path, aligning perfectly with their commitment to self-determination and regional stability in the Western Balkans.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the call for visa liberalization to end Kosovo’s isolation, emphasizing this as critical for fostering youth engagement and cross-border dialogue central to GREEN_EFA’s human mobility principles.  
GREEN_EFA endorses transforming the EU Liaison Office into a full delegation, enhancing institutional coherence and mirroring their advocacy for robust EU diplomatic presence in conflict-affected regions.  
GREEN_EFA proposes reinforcing the amendment on impartial investigations into recent violence by mandating EULEX oversight, ensuring accountability without delaying broader reforms.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s alignment with their peacebuilding agenda through its emphasis on Serbia-Kosovo pragmatic cooperation, particularly regarding CEFTA integration and parallel structure dismantling.

ALDE strongly endorses the issue's emphasis on Kosovo's European integration as aligning perfectly with ALDE's commitment to Western Balkan stability through EU values-based cooperation.  
ALDE applauds the focus on Serbia-Kosovo dialogue enhancement, particularly condemning the attack on Petar Miletić as antithetical to democratic norms, and urges accelerated EU-mediated security reforms in Serbian enclaves.  
ALDE proposes strengthening economic conditionality by specifying agricultural modernization targets in Article 14 to address 40% unemployment while maintaining full endorsement of the growth strategy.  
ALDE firmly approves calls for unified EU recognition of Kosovo, echoing Ms. Bilbao's appeal to Spain and others to resolve recognition inconsistencies that undermine policy coherence.  
ALDE emphasizes the need for pre-electoral consensus-building mechanisms in Kosovo to avoid Albanian-style political polarization, framing this as an enhancement opportunity under the issue's public administration reforms.

SD supports the issue’s push for Kosovo’s European integration but advises ensuring dialogue between Serbia and Kosovo remains balanced, urging mutual concessions rather than unilateral demands.  
SD endorses transforming the EU Liaison Office into a full delegation to streamline policy coherence, aligning with Lisbon Treaty objectives for a unified external action framework.  
SD highlights the need for EU Member States to reconcile divergent positions on Kosovo’s status, emphasizing adherence to international law while pragmatically advancing integration.  
SD advises prioritizing agricultural reforms and infrastructure investments to address unemployment, coupled with EU-backed green energy initiatives for sustainable growth.  
SD stresses strengthening minority protections and cultural heritage preservation, urging explicit inclusion of Roma communities in education and anti-discrimination measures.

GUE/NGL rejects the issue's premise of Kosovo's EU integration as fundamentally illegal under UN Security Council Resolution 1244, which affirms Serbian sovereignty.  
GUE/NGL opposes the EU's endorsement of Kosovo's unilateral independence as a violation of international law that institutionalizes partition through past NATO violence rather than negotiated solutions.  
GUE/NGL condemns the issue for ignoring Kosovo's economic non-viability and dependence on foreign criminal networks, contradicting principles of self-determination.  
GUE/NGL highlights the issue's failure to address the destabilizing prospect of "Greater Albania" through ethnically divided states, exacerbating regional tensions.  
GUE/NGL entirely disapproves with the issue's alignment with double-standard diplomacy that rewards secessionism while demanding territorial integrity elsewhere.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of Kosovo’s European integration, emphasizing the EU’s commitment to its eventual accession conditioned on reforms in rule of law, anti-corruption, judiciary independence, public administration, and human rights. It noted Kosovo’s 2008 declaration of independence, recognized by 69 countries including 22 EU states, and urged remaining Member States to align their approach to enhance EU policy coherence. The resolution stressed the need for visa liberalization for Kosovo citizens once conditions are met, addressing their isolation compared to neighboring Western Balkan states. It highlighted concerns over Serbia-Kosovo relations, urging Serbia to cease support for parallel structures in Kosovo’s Serbian enclaves and cooperate pragmatically, including through regional integration under CEFTA and resolving disputes over Kosovo’s international membership. The EULEX mission’s role in strengthening rule of law was underscored, with calls to address high-level corruption, organized crime, and war crimes, while improving transparency and staffing. Economic challenges were emphasized, including 40% unemployment, poverty, and the need for sustainable growth through agricultural reforms, energy security, and infrastructure development, alongside environmental protection. The resolution urged protection of minorities, including Roma, and stressed cultural heritage preservation, education reforms promoting multilingualism, and civil society support. It called for swift implementation of missing persons resolutions (1,862 cases unresolved) and improved conditions for refugee returns. Lastly, it advocated transforming the EU Liaison Office into a full delegation to streamline EU presence, aligning with the European External Action Service post-Lisbon Treaty.

title: Impact of the financial crisis on the defence sector: REPORT on the impact of the financial crisis on the defence sector in the EU Member States
background: The 2008 global financial crisis and subsequent eurozone debt challenges prompted EU member states to reduce defense budgets, exacerbating existing military capability gaps and disproportionate reliance on US security guarantees. Persistent fragmentation in national defense planning created redundancies across European military capacities. The Parliament will discuss financial crisis impacts on EU defense sectors, budget constraints, capability sustainability, and cooperative security frameworks.

stances.stance:
EPP completely endorses the issue's emphasis on permanent structured cooperation under the Lisbon Treaty, perfectly aligning with their longstanding commitment to multinational capability development and shared operational frameworks.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the call for harmonized defense planning through the European Defence Agency, recognizing this as critical to eliminating duplication and achieving €200 billion efficiency gains.  
EPP unequivocally supports the issue's demand for pooled strategic transport fleets, seeing this as the only viable path to maintain Europe’s peacekeeping capacity amid budget constraints.  
EPP completely agrees with the proposal to allocate 2% of GDP to defense budgets with shared R&D priorities, matching their manifesto commitment to close the innovation gap with global competitors.  
EPP fully backs the creation of a single European defense equipment market, affirming that Directive 2009/43/EC implementation is essential to overcome fragmentation and "juste retour" inefficiencies.

GREEN_EFA rejects the diversion of Horizon 2020 funds to military research, entirely disputeing with their commitment to civilian innovation and peace-oriented science.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the allocation of EU Structural Funds to defense industries, viewing this as a reckless misprioritization during social austerity crises.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue’s tacit acceptance of opaque procurement practices, inconsistent with their demands for full transparency and anti-corruption reforms.  
GREEN_EFA denounces the reported arms-for-bailout agreements as militaristic exploitation of fiscal emergencies, irreconcilable with their anti-war and social justice principles.  
GREEN_EFA opposes increased NATO spending mandates, which perpetuate dependency on external security frameworks they seek to dismantle.

ALDE strongly approves the issue’s emphasis on pooled capabilities and harmonized defense planning via the European Defence Agency, aligning perfectly with ALDE’s commitment to strategic autonomy and integrated EU security frameworks.  
ALDE approves the call for a single European defense equipment market and transparency in procurement, proposing strict adherence to Directives 2009/43/EC and 2009/81/EC by codifying explicit prohibitions on offset practices to eliminate market distortions.  
ALDE applauds the focus on collaborative R&D and civil-military research synergies through Horizon 2020, urging accelerated EU funding for GMES and the European Security and Defence College to address critical technological gaps.  
ALDE underscores the need to prioritize anti-corruption measures in defense procurement, advocating for mandatory audits under the EU code of conduct to safeguard budget integrity and public trust.  
ALDE highlights the urgency of extending interoperability efforts to maritime security domains, ensuring pooled strategic transport capabilities address operational gaps like piracy protection for EU assets.

SD strongly upholds the issue’s emphasis on EU defense cooperation and pooled capabilities, aligning perfectly with SD’s longstanding commitment to European solidarity and strategic autonomy through shared resources like air transport fleets.  
SD strongly approves the call to harmonize defense planning via the European Defence Agency, noting this effectively advances SD’s priority of eliminating inefficiencies and duplication in fragmented national budgets.  
SD strongly endorses the push for a single European defense equipment market and transparency in procurement, proposing expanding Directive 2009/81/EC to include stricter anti-corruption clauses addressing offset system abuses highlighted in the debate.  
SD urges consideration of tailored support for Member States facing unique security challenges, such as Cyprus’s territorial defense needs, to ensure inclusive implementation of pooling initiatives without compromising national sovereignty.  
SD applauds the focus on reallocating resources to critical gaps like cyber defense and R&D, while suggesting accelerated timelines for aligning Horizon 2020 funding with dual-use technologies to address underinvestment.  
 Ana Gomes’ critique of nuclear arsenals is reframed as an enhancement opportunity to redirect savings toward EU-wide defense priorities.

ECR rejects the issue’s emphasis on EU defense integration as a dangerous distraction from NATO’s proven role in ensuring collective security.  
ECR opposes the concept of EU strategic autonomy, arguing it duplicates NATO structures and undermines reliance on the U.S. as Europe’s primary military ally.  
ECR fully opposes with proposals for pooled capabilities, citing the Libya intervention’s failure where EU members withdrew critical assets like AWACS support.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of operational reliability, as ECR stresses only sovereign NATO commitments ensure “solid, reliable allies” during crises.  
ECR dismisses EU defense market harmonization, asserting fragmented planning reflects national sovereignty and rejects “forced comparisons” to U.S. spending efficiency.

GUE/NGL rejects the issue's militarization agenda as absolutely challengeing with their commitment to radical disarmament and civilian EU priorities.  
GUE/NGL opposes the emphasis on NATO alignment and Lisbon Treaty militarization, citing incompatibility with anti-war principles and social justice imperatives.  
GUE/NGL condemns the false narrative linking defense cuts to unemployment, stressing that redirected funds could address hunger and public infrastructure crises.  
GUE/NGL highlights democratic risks in proposals like the ATHENA mechanism, which bypasses parliamentary oversight and merges civilian-military capabilities.  
GUE/NGL underscores the issue’s failure to address systemic capitalist exploitation, framing military spending as an extension of anti-social austerity policies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over significant cuts to EU Member States' defense budgets amid financial crises, warning that uncoordinated reductions risk irreversible loss of military capabilities and undermine the EU’s ability to fulfill peacekeeping and international security responsibilities. It highlighted Europe’s disproportionate reliance on the U.S., noting that 75% of NATO defense spending comes from the U.S., while EU states collectively spend €200 billion annually—a third of the U.S. budget—but suffer inefficiencies due to fragmented planning, duplication, and underinvestment in critical areas like strategic transport, cyber defense, and R&D (with only 1% of defense budgets allocated to research and technology). The resolution urged enhanced EU cooperation through pooled capabilities (e.g., air transport fleets, shared aircraft carriers), harmonized defense planning via the European Defence Agency (EDA), and permanent structured cooperation under the Lisbon Treaty to boost strategic autonomy. It called for reforms to establish a single European defense equipment market, enforce transparency in procurement (citing Directives 2009/43/EC and 2009/81/EC), and eliminate barriers like "juste retour" practices. The Parliament stressed the need to increase collaborative R&D, align civilian and military research (notably via Horizon 2020), and secure EU funding for initiatives like the European Security and Defence College and satellite capabilities (e.g., GMES). It warned that failure to address fragmentation and underfunding would perpetuate dependency on external actors, as seen in the Libya intervention, and undermine Europe’s global security role.

title: Implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy: REPORT on the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy (based on the Annual Report from the Council to the European Parliament on the Common Foreign and Security Policy)
background: Heightened geopolitical threats, including instability in the EU’s southern neighborhood, maritime security risks, cyber vulnerabilities, and defense budget constraints due to economic crises, alongside evolving EU treaties and strategies, shaped discussions on strengthening the Common Security and Defence Policy. The Parliament will discuss enhancing CSDP effectiveness, defense capabilities, and industrial competitiveness.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees the issue's emphasis on strategic autonomy through enhanced CSDP capabilities, aligning with EPP's commitment to a geopolitically sovereign EU.  
EPP approves the full utilization of Lisbon Treaty instruments including PESCO and operational headquarters to address rapid deployment needs in crisis management.  
EPP emphasizes the critical need for defense industry consolidation and SME integration to maintain technological leadership, mirroring EPP's 2023 industrial competitiveness priorities.  
EPP proposes accelerating defense production harmonization to eliminate redundant systems across member states, enhancing cost-efficiency while maintaining interoperability goals.  
EPP endorses establishing a Council of Defence Ministers and revised Security Strategy as vital steps toward operational coherence, reflecting EPP's institutional reform agenda.

EFD rejects the creation of permanent EU military structures and operational headquarters as a dangerous move toward eroding national sovereignty and establishing a supranational European army.  
EFD opposes centralized defense procurement initiatives, citing Greece’s experience with exploitative overpricing and political corruption in EU-driven military contracts.  
EFD absolutely opposes with the issue’s emphasis on mutual defense clauses, arguing these mechanisms ignore vulnerabilities of border states like Greece to external threats while enabling EU interference in national security priorities.  
EFD condemns EU pressure to increase defense spending as economically destructive, highlighting how forced budget allocations exacerbated Greece’s debt crisis through unsustainable military expenditures.  
EFD rejects deeper EU-NATO integration, asserting that subordinating national armed forces to collective command structures undermines Britain’s strategic autonomy and military readiness.

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's emphasis on military operational headquarters and defense industry consolidation as totally disapproveing with their commitment to conflict prevention and demilitarized security frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the proposed EU budget allocations for defense R&D and drone programs, citing unresolved ethical concerns and inconsistency with their stance against lethal autonomous weapons systems.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue’s linkage of CSDP to energy security and external border protection, which overlooks critical aspects of human rights prioritization and civil crisis management capacities.  
GREEN_EFA challenges the issue’s focus on defense market job creation, asserting this contradicts their principles of transparent procurement rules and demilitarized economic priorities.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s failure to address wasteful defense spending duplication, a core concern raised in the debate about inefficient resource use across Member States.

ALDE strongly accepts the issue’s emphasis on pooling and sharing defense capabilities through PESCO and the European Defence Agency, aligning perfectly with ALDE’s longstanding commitment to strategic autonomy and a consolidated EU defense market.  
ALDE approves the roadmap for clustered defense planning among politically willing states, which effectively advances ALDE’s priority of rationalizing taxpayer spending while amplifying EU crisis-response visibility.  
ALDE applauds the focus on integrating human rights and democratic oversight into CSDP missions, a principle central to ALDE’s vision of ethical and comprehensive security governance.  
ALDE proposes enhancing the cybersecurity provisions by explicitly addressing unchecked exports of surveillance technologies, ensuring coherence with human rights standards and preventing digital arms proliferation.  
ALDE underscores the urgency of clarifying command structures for emerging defense technologies like drones, suggesting amendments to Article 46 to formalize multilateral authorization protocols.

SD supports the issue's emphasis on strategic autonomy and addressing defense budget cuts through pooling and sharing initiatives, aligning with S&D's call to prevent capability losses in member states like Portugal.  
SD advises revising CSDP mission financing mechanisms to alleviate financial burdens on contributing states, ensuring equitable cost-sharing and operational sustainability.  
SD proposes strict anti-corruption measures in defense procurement, explicitly banning offset agreements linked to past scandals such as submarine deals in Portugal and Greece.  
SD supports enhancing the European defense industry's competitiveness through coordinated R&D investments and normalized equipment standards, while cautioning against protectionist policies that limit global market access.  
SD highlights the need to integrate a revised European Security Strategy with democratic governance promotion in the Mediterranean neighborhood, linking security objectives to regional stability and human rights.

GUE/NGL entirely doubts the issue's militarization agenda, viewing permanent structured cooperation (PESCO) and EU battle groups as steps toward an imperialist "European army" that prioritizes resource control over peace.  
GUE/NGL rejects the normalization of EU-NATO collaboration, arguing it entrenches neocolonial interventions and contradicts claims of strategic autonomy by subordinating Europe to U.S. geopolitical interests.  
GUE/NGL condemns the issue's promotion of arms industry consolidation, highlighting how EU weapons exports directly fuel global conflicts that displace millions and violate human rights.  
GUE/NGL opposes the framing of cybersecurity and energy security through military lenses, stressing that austerity-driven privatization—not defense gaps—creates vulnerabilities exploited by far-right and corporate powers.  
GUE/NGL denounces the hypocrisy of invoking "democratic values" while ignoring Turkey's occupation of Cyprus and EU states' surveillance technology sales to authoritarian regimes.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about evolving geopolitical threats, including transnational terrorism, energy insecurity, cyber threats, financial crises impacting defense budgets, and instability in the EU’s southern neighborhood. It emphasized the need for strategic autonomy and a strengthened Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) to enhance the EU’s global role, crisis management, and citizen security. The resolution called for leveraging Lisbon Treaty instruments like permanent structured cooperation (PESCO), a CSDP start-up fund, and a permanent military operational headquarters to improve decision-making, rapid deployment, and mission effectiveness. It highlighted shortcomings in CSDP missions, particularly in Libya and Mali, and urged reforms to accelerate civilian mission deployment, enhance mediation capacities, and integrate human rights and gender perspectives. The Parliament stressed the urgency of addressing defense capability gaps through pooling and sharing initiatives, revising the Capability Development Plan, and strengthening the European Defence Agency’s role. It advocated for a competitive EU defense industry via a consolidated internal market, R&D investments, and support for SMEs, while emphasizing energy efficiency in defense and cybersecurity cooperation. The resolution urged closer EU-NATO collaboration, a maritime security strategy, and activation of mutual defense and solidarity clauses for critical infrastructure protection. It called for a December 2013 European Council roadmap with benchmarks, regular reviews, and a future Council of Defence Ministers to sustain momentum. The Parliament also highlighted the need for a revised European Security Strategy, a White Paper on defense, and public engagement to link security with democratic values and prosperity.

title: Motions for resolutions - A political solution with regard to the piracy off the Somalian coast: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on a political solution to the problem of piracy off the Somali coast
background: Persistent piracy off Somalia's coast since 2008, exacerbated by state fragility, humanitarian crises, and regional instability, prompted international naval responses including EU Operation Atalanta and UN Security Council resolutions. The Parliament will discuss a political strategy addressing piracy's root causes, enhancing EU coordination, and strengthening regional judicial cooperation.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts the extension of EUNAVFOR Atalanta as a critical tool in maritime security, aligning with EPP's commitment to robust multilateral responses against piracy while safeguarding humanitarian corridors.  
EPP emphasizes enhancing Somalia's governance capacity through sustained EU engagement, directly advancing the issue's focus on addressing piracy's root causes via political stabilization and economic development programs.  
EPP endorses strict adherence to legal frameworks for prosecuting pirates, proposing strengthened monitoring mechanisms to ensure fishing agreements respect Somali sovereignty while protecting legitimate EU fleet operations.  
EPP advocates classifying vulnerable tuna vessels as priority protection targets under Atalanta's mandate, suggesting operational adjustments to account for their unique risks during fishing activities.  
EPP approves integrating counter-piracy efforts with AMISOM stabilization missions, reinforcing the issue's call for coordinated regional strategies that combine naval deterrence with institution-building.

EFD partially upholds the issue’s recognition of political stability as a priority but requests explicit language prioritizing governance investments over naval operations in Article 5.  
EFD finds the issue inconsistent with its emphasis on root-cause solutions, as Section 3 allocates 70% of funding to military efforts while merely "referencing" development goals.  
The proposal overlooks mandatory transparency mechanisms for tracking political progress, which EFD insists must be amended to include quarterly reporting to Parliament on Somali governance benchmarks.  
EFD demands revisions to Clause 8 to specify direct EU support for local Somali judicial institutions rather than relying solely on third-state prosecution agreements.

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's expansion of military operations as fundamentally inconsistent with their principle of addressing systemic governance failures and environmental crimes enabling piracy.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the proposed ESDP training mission for lacking a demonstrable link to Somali state-building and risking armed escalation through potential misuse of trained forces by warlords.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue’s inadequate focus on combating illegal fishing and toxic waste dumping by external actors, which directly contradicts their demand for accountability in maritime resource exploitation.  
GREEN_EFA challenges the legitimacy of supporting Somalia’s transitional government without clear mechanisms to ensure trained soldiers strengthen civil institutions rather than factional power structures.  
GREEN_EFA asserts that prioritizing naval deterrence over prosecuting illegal foreign exploitation of Somali waters perpetuates the economic desperation fueling piracy, violating their environmental justice commitments.

ALDE strongly approves the issue’s emphasis on addressing piracy’s root causes through Somalia’s political stability, aligning perfectly with ALDE’s commitment to governance-driven security solutions.  
ALDE approves the prioritization of legal frameworks with Kenya and Seychelles for prosecuting pirates, which effectively advances regional judicial cooperation as outlined in ALDE’s principles.  
ALDE proposes extending Operation Atalanta’s protection to European fishing vessels in the Indian Ocean, enhancing parity with merchant ship safeguards while maintaining the issue’s core objectives.  
ALDE highlights the urgency of implementing International Maritime Organization recommendations on military escorts, framing this as a cost-effective enhancement to existing naval patrol efforts.  
ALDE applauds the alignment between counter-piracy operations and long-term development goals, consistent with their manifesto’s integrated approach to maritime security and humanitarian protection.

SD strongly promotes the EUNAVFOR Atalanta mission’s demonstrated success in safeguarding maritime trade routes and enabling critical humanitarian aid delivery, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to multilateral security and development.  

SD approves the issue’s prioritization of Somalia’s political stabilization through support for the Djibouti Peace Agreement, emphasizing that sustained governance reforms are essential to eradicating piracy’s socioeconomic drivers.  

SD proposes enhancing Atalanta’s mandate to include surveillance of coastal ports used by pirate networks and expanding protected zones for fishing vessels, ensuring both immediate threat reduction and alignment with long-term state-building objectives.  

SD advocates for parallel EU capacity-building missions to train Somali security forces under strict human rights oversight, reinforcing the nexus between military deterrence and institutional legitimacy.  

SD underscores the urgency of integrating naval operations with increased development aid and regional diplomacy, urging the Council to convene a piracy summit for coordinated land-sea strategies.

GUE_NGL completely conflicts the issue's reliance on EUNAVFOR Atalanta's military operations, contradicting their principle that "no maritime solution to piracy is possible" through armed force.  
GUE_NGL rejects the prioritization of naval patrols and prosecution frameworks while failing to prohibit privatization of military security functions, which they condemn as corporate militarization.  
GUE_NGL asserts the issue inadequately addresses foreign exploitation of Somali waters - labeled "foreign piracy" by Meyer - that perpetuates coastal instability.  
GUE_NGL disputes the claimed alignment between military actions and governance goals, arguing the text institutionalizes militarized responses over development-based solutions.  
GUE_NGL demands complete cessation of all piracy forms rather than selective targeting, a balance absent from the issue's counter-piracy strategies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over escalating piracy off Somalia’s coast and endorsed EUNAVFOR Atalanta, the EU’s military operation launched in December 2008 to deter piracy through naval patrols, protection of humanitarian shipments, and collaboration with international partners. It highlighted the importance of UN Security Council resolutions (1814 to 1972, 2008–2009) enabling international intervention in Somali waters and stressed the need for legal frameworks, including agreements with Kenya (2008) and Seychelles (2009), to transfer and prosecute suspected pirates. The resolution emphasized addressing root causes of piracy by supporting Somalia’s political stability, referencing the Djibouti Peace Agreement’s call for a unity government and inclusive parliament. It urged enhanced regional cooperation, comprehensive counter-piracy strategies, and sustained EU engagement to safeguard maritime routes and civilian lives while aligning military efforts with long-term governance and development goals in Somalia.

title: Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance (IPA II)
background: The EU’s pre-accession assistance framework (IPA I) supported reforms in candidate countries to align with EU standards, amid ongoing enlargement processes and geopolitical priorities in the Western Balkans and Turkey. The Parliament will discuss the proposed IPA II regulation to structure financial support for accession-related reforms and regional cooperation.

stances.stance:
EPP entirely endorses the horizontal coherence framework, perfectly aligning with EPP's commitment to conflict prevention through flexible fund allocation (21% crisis response reserve) and pandemic preparedness mechanisms.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the strengthened European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights, particularly its 25% budget allocation for election observation missions, advancing EPP's priority of democratic governance in transitional states.  
EPP entirely endorses the 3% budget increase for external action, effectively advancing strategic partnerships with Latin America and implementation of the "more for more" principle in neighborhood policy.  
EPP strongly approves the neighborhood instrument's focus on educational exchanges and women's rights protection, reflecting EPP's foundational values of societal stability through value-based cooperation.  
EPP entirely endorses enhanced parliamentary scrutiny over human rights funding, proposing strengthened cybersecurity provisions by strictly limiting assistance to cross-border organized cybercrime and terrorist attacks per the Budapest Convention.

EFD partially endorses the IPA II framework but requests revisions to Article 5 to include strict expenditure ceilings, citing incompatibility with EFD's principle of taxpayer protection.  
EFD opposes the expansion of EU diplomatic infrastructure under IPA II, highlighting the issue's failure to address duplication of national foreign policy functions as outlined in Recital 12.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of fiscal accountability by permitting salary packages exceeding national executive compensation levels, contradicting EFD's demands for austerity in EU operational budgets.  
This fundamentally rejects with EFD's position that EU external action should strictly supplement rather than replace member states' bilateral diplomacy networks, requiring amendment to Section 7(b) on delegation mandates.  
EFD requests deletion of provisions enabling new budgetary commitments without member state ratification, maintaining such allocations violate core subsidiarity principles affirmed in EFD manifestos.

GREEN_EFA entirely upholds the centrality of democratic reforms and civil society empowerment in IPA II, perfectly aligning with their mandate to prioritize rule of law and participatory governance.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the codification of "more for more" conditionality as a strategic mechanism to reward ambitious democratic transformations while insulating civil society from punitive measures.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s operationalization of human rights indicators as critical to measurable progress, reflecting their decade-long advocacy for accountability frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA strongly accepts the institutional recognition of civil society’s role across policy cycles, seeing this as foundational to achieving sustainable development partnerships.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the issue’s procedural rigor in maintaining parliamentary oversight, ensuring coherence with their principles of democratic conditionality in external financing.

ALDE strongly agrees the enhanced focus on civil society engagement and visibility of EU assistance, aligning with their commitment to tangible democratic reforms in accession countries.  
ALDE approves the strategic prioritization of judiciary reforms under Chapters 23-24, effectively advancing their priority of rule-of-law conditionality in pre-accession processes.  
ALDE proposes strengthening transparency mechanisms to ensure IPA II funds directly benefit citizens, reflecting their longstanding advocacy for accountability in external action.  
ALDE endorses the partnership instrument’s role in globalizing Europe 2020 Strategy objectives, particularly in improving market access and EU visibility worldwide.  
ALDE recommends amplifying local communication strategies to make EU assistance "otipljiva" (tangible), addressing citizen awareness gaps while maintaining procedural rigor.

SD strongly sanctions the enhanced parliamentary oversight and transparency requirements for fund allocation, aligning perfectly with SD's longstanding commitment to accountable EU external action.  
SD approves the anchoring of democracy and human rights conditionality across assistance programs, effectively advancing SD's priority of principled global engagement.  
SD applauds the increased focus on civil society capacity-building in partner countries as matching SD's manifesto goals for grassroots democratic development.  
SD proposes extending consultation timelines with local stakeholders by 15 days during program design phases to deepen participatory implementation without opposing the issue's core mechanisms.  
SD strongly sanctions the preservation of development aid for middle-income countries' social services, reflecting SD's 2023 pledge to combat inequality through targeted poverty eradication measures.

GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the issue's failure to enforce binding parliamentary oversight, as non-binding declarations like "strategic dialogue" contradict their demand for accountability in external interventions.  
GUE_NGL rejects the conditionalities imposing deregulation and privatization on pre-accession states, deeming this inconsistent with their opposition to exploitative economic policies globally.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue’s alignment with EU security interests over self-determination, exemplified by its application in occupied Palestinian territories and Western Sahara, violating sovereignty principles.  
GUE_NGL criticizes the regression to outdated comitology procedures for funding instruments, which undermines transparency and parliamentary authority after ineffective trilogue negotiations.  
GUE_NGL condemns the prioritization of geopolitical strategies over democratic scrutiny, enabling repressive regimes through militarized aid programs like those in the Congo.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position by adopting the resolution on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0838), endorsing parliamentary and joint statements with the Council and Commission while acknowledging annexed Commission statements. It emphasized the need for the Commission to reconsult Parliament if proposing substantial amendments or replacing the text, ensuring procedural accountability. The resolution instructed the President to formally transmit Parliament’s adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, finalizing its legislative input under Article 294 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The process incorporated opinions from the European Economic and Social Committee (2012) and the Committee of the Regions (2012), aligning institutional perspectives without specifying numerical targets or policy details beyond procedural adherence.

title: Instrument for Stability: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1717/2006 establishing an Instrument for Stability
background: The European Parliament's review of the 2006 Instrument for Stability followed a 2008 Court of Justice ruling annulling a Council decision on small arms and light weapons (SALW) and the post-Lisbon Treaty institutional reforms. The Parliament will discuss amendments to the regulation addressing SALW inclusion, funding allocations, and delegated act procedures.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees the enhanced parliamentary oversight mechanisms in the amended Instrument for Stability, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to institutional balance under the Lisbon Treaty.  
EPP applauds the increased funding ceiling for crisis prevention measures as effectively advancing EPP's priority of proactive conflict issue and civil society empowerment.  
EPP proposes streamlining grant application processes for grassroots democracy initiatives to enhance accessibility while fully maintaining rigorous accountability standards.  
EPP strongly endorses the explicit recognition of Parliament’s veto rights over delegated acts, ensuring democratic scrutiny matches the EU’s elevated global governance role.  
EPP emphasizes optimizing implementation timelines for democracy instruments in contested regions like Transnistria to maximize operational impact without opposing the issue’s core framework.

EFD supports addressing the legal framework gaps identified by the Court but urges rigorous scrutiny of the €2 billion allocation to ensure taxpayer funds directly enhance stability initiatives.  
EFD advises amending budget provisions to redirect resources from new taxes towards growth measures, including reducing MEP salaries and travel allowances as a fiscal responsibility model.  
EFD proposes revising Annex II's country list to exclude regimes where EU contributions risk unintended military modernisation, aligning cooperation with democratic governance principles.

GREEN_EFA strongly sanctions enhanced parliamentary oversight of development funds, aligning with their commitment to ensuring EU aid strictly adheres to poverty eradication goals as mandated in the issue.  
GREEN_EFA proposes exploring flexible financing models akin to US mechanisms for democratization projects, enhancing the Instrument for Stability’s responsiveness without opposing its core legal framework.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s emphasis on environmental and labor standards, which directly advance their manifesto priorities for sustainable agricultural reforms and pesticide regulation.  
GREEN_EFA endorses strict scrutiny of ODA compliance to maintain public trust, reflecting their longstanding demand for transparency in EU external spending.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes integrating small producer protections into stability instruments, urging explicit alignment with international fair trade benchmarks in implementation.

ALDE strongly upholds the issue's enhanced focus on combating small arms trafficking and involving civil society organizations, aligning perfectly with ALDE's commitment to grassroots-driven peacebuilding and conflict prevention.  
ALDE approves the legal adjustments reinforcing parliamentary oversight mechanisms, effectively advancing institutional accountability in EU foreign policy implementation as mandated by the Court of Justice ruling.  
ALDE applauds the Instrument for Stability's innovative crisis-response tools, which match ALDE's longstanding advocacy for proactive international engagement through structured peacebuilding frameworks.  
ALDE proposes a minor technical amendment to explore integrating the European Development Fund into the EU budget, enhancing financial transparency and policy coherence while fully supporting the issue's core objectives.  
ALDE endorses the commitment to periodic evaluation of foreign policy instruments, reflecting ALDE's principle of adaptive governance to maintain EU effectiveness in global stability efforts.

SD strongly upholds the issue’s reinforcement of parliamentary oversight in foreign affairs, aligning perfectly with S&D’s longstanding commitment to institutional accountability and democratic scrutiny post-Lisbon Treaty.  
SD approves the amended Commission proposal to address legal gaps in external action frameworks, emphasizing the necessity of additional funding for democracy promotion while safeguarding resources for the poorest nations.  
SD proposes enhancing the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights by establishing a cross-party foundation to bolster grassroots democratic movements, ensuring flexibility akin to the US National Endowment for Democracy.  
SD underscores the imperative of transparency in Commission strategy papers and annual reports, advancing S&D’s priority of legitimizing EU external policy through rigorous accountability mechanisms.  
SD advocates for sustained budgetary commitments to development cooperation, firmly opposing any reduction to instruments critical for poverty eradication and human rights advancement.

GUE_NGL rejects the Instrument for Stability amendment as enabling undemocratic foreign interventions that contradict anti-imperialist principles.  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the neoliberal trade framework embedded in development policies which prioritizes corporate profits over small producers' survival.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue's failure to address EU complicity in austerity programs exacerbating global poverty through bank bailouts and public service cuts.  
GUE_NGL declares the democracy promotion mechanisms illegitimate given the EU's own democratic deficits in voter disengagement and media-dominated governance structures.  
GUE_NGL rejects military-aligned spending under stability instruments as proven counterproductive by Afghanistan's destabilization despite massive funding.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the annulment of Council Decision 2004/833/CFSP by the Court of Justice in Case C-91/05, which had implemented a Joint Action supporting ECOWAS under the Moratorium on Small Arms and Light Weapons. It approved the amended Commission proposal COM(2009)0195, aimed at addressing legal gaps following the court’s judgment, and instructed the Commission to resubmit the matter to Parliament if proposing significant amendments or replacements. The resolution emphasized adherence to procedural safeguards to ensure parliamentary oversight, particularly in foreign affairs and development cooperation, and directed its President to formally communicate Parliament’s position to the Council and Commission, reinforcing institutional accountability in EU external action frameworks.

title: Instrument for stability: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing an Instrument for Stability
background: The European Union sought to update its external action financial framework post-Lisbon Treaty, addressing global security challenges, conflict prevention, and democratic transitions following regional instability, including the Arab Spring. The Parliament will discuss establishing a regulatory instrument to enhance EU crisis response, stability, and development cooperation capabilities.

stances.stance:
EPP entirely approves the horizontal approach to external action instruments, perfectly aligning with its commitment to coherent EU crisis response and conflict prevention through enhanced complementarity between funding mechanisms.  
EPP applauds the issue's focus on public health emergency preparedness, effectively advancing the Union's role in global health security as a core stability priority.
